_README: Manual data additions for the TN Governor Race Tracker. Scrapers NEVER touch this file. The merge step (merge.py) combines this with scraped data to produce the final output files. Manual entries always win on conflicts.

sources.name: Tennesseans for Student Success / Victory Phones
sources.methodology: IVR automated telephone survey of registered voters
sources.note: Education-focused statewide poll commissioned by Tennesseans for Student Success. Feb 2026 survey included governor's race horse race plus 20+ education policy questions.

polls.pollster: Tennesseans for Student Success / Victory Phones

School Choice / Tax Credit.note: 71.3% support public school choice; 82.3% support open enrollment

Student Testing & Accountability.note: 81.2% say annual student testing is important
87.3% support holding schools and teachers accountable

Education Spending Efficiency.note: Only 35.7% believe education funding is spent efficiently; 64.3% say it is NOT

trendline.description: Tracking Blackburn's primary support from Jan 2025 to Feb 2026: 71.0% to 60.6%. After dipping to 56% in January, Blackburn rebounded in the TSS poll. Undecided voters remain the key battleground at 26.1%.

polls.analysis: Across 6 primary polls and 2 general election polls from 4 pollsters (Targoz/Beacon Center, Quantus Insights, Fabrizio Lee, TSS/Victory Phones), Blackburn leads the GOP primary at 60.6% in the latest survey (Feb 2026), followed by Rose (8.1%) and Fritts (5.1%). The undecided pool remains significant at 26.1%. All four major race raters classify this as Solid/Safe Republican.

articles.title: New Statewide Poll: Blackburn at 60.6%, Voters Overwhelmingly Back Education Accountability
articles.summary: A new survey of 500 Tennessee registered voters by Tennesseans for Student Success finds Sen. Marsha Blackburn leading the GOP primary at 60.6%, with Rep. John Rose at 8.1% and Rep. Monty Fritts at 5.1%. The poll also reveals broad education consensus: 87% support holding schools accountable, 82% back open enrollment, 81% say annual testing matters, and 64% believe education funding is not spent efficiently.
